awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Eric G. Ramos is "Commutative and Asymptotic Algebra." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Andrew Snowden.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The following Project Outcomes Report summarizes the accomplishments of the PI during the life of the award DMS-1704811, titled "Asymptotic and Commutative Algebra." Before setting out on this summary, we take a moment to understand the three main words in the title, "Asymptotic," "Commutative," and "Algebra." Broadly speaking, modern algebra refers to the study of numerical systems, whose rules are chosen to fit a given context. For instance, one can choose to work with the algebra where 3 is set equal to zero, and study how this numerical system compares with the more standard numerical system of the integers. The word commutative refers to the fact that one insists that our algebra contain a rule that the product of two terms does not depend on the order in which the product is performed in. Finally, asymptotic relates with the study of objects which are getting bigger and bigger, in the appropriate sense, while asking what kinds of behaviors emerge when the object is big enough.

Much of what was initially presented in the description of this award was in understanding the algebra of what are known as FI-modules. One can think of an FI-module as a sequence of changing and growing numerical systems, which are intricately related with one another. These objects naturally arise from the study of topology, where one literally builds bigger and bigger spaces, one on top of the other, while associating a numerical system at each step. Thanks to the generous support granted to the PI by this award, he was able to prove many things about FI-modules and other related objects. While supported by the award, the PI produced 15 papers that vastly expanded the state of the art in the subject. These works were all published in the most premier journals in the field such as "Advances in Mathematics," and "International Mathematics Research Notices," and pulled from an eclectic range of mathematical disciplines such as Combinatorics, Topology, Geometry, and Probability. Perhaps the most significant result of all these works is a proof of the so-called Categorical Graph Minor Theorem, joint with Nicholas Proudfoot and Dane Miyata, which was used to prove non-trivial facts about spaces known as Graph Configuration Spaces, as well as spaces known as Matching Complexes. Keeping with the theme of asymptotic algebra, what these results said was that certain families of numerical systems associated with these spaces had extremely predictable torsion as soon as they got big enough.

It should be noted that these 15 papers include work with 10 coauthors, some of whom were present at the PI's host institutions, while others were stationed in institutions such as Standford University and the University of California San Diego. These collaborations were made possible through the grant, as it allowed the PI to travel frequently to meet and collaborate with these coauthors. The PI also gave talks on these works at numerous institutions across the United States and Europe.

During the life of the award the PI was stationed at two universities, the University of Michigan, as well as the University of Oregon. While at the University of Michigan, the PI ran a small reading group with a collection of eager undergraduates. It has always been the PI's belief that these kinds of reading groups were critical for outreach to the next generation of mathematicians, and he was thrilled to be able to use the freedom granted by having this award to run such a group. While at the University of Oregon, the PI continued this mentorship trend by aiding in the mathematical development of the graduate student Dane Miyata. The PI also participated in virutal mentorship opportunities, guiding undergraduate students from underrepresented communities apply to graduate school.

Modified by: Eric G Ramos
